review_title: Quality of Institution Depends on Department and Supervisors
pros: The work/life balance and benefits are great. The area and campus is beautiful. Really like the President and what she's working towards.
cons:
I was at Amherst for several years and experienced very different attitudes from different departments. Some departments were great to be in and those employees enjoyed pay increases as well as promotions. Other departments struggled and when turnover was high under a specific manager, the solution was instead to promote that specific, troublesome manager. While everyone commonly said that I deserved more (including my supervisor) a promotion never came even though I was promised one month after month. When I gave my notice (of close to a month), I was told to stay for two months more if I "really wanted to leave on a good note."

My advice for you, negotiate before accepting an offer, as that may be the last time you'll be able to without a promotion (biggest increases for "outstanding" performance on a review is something like 3%).

When I expressed my frustrations during my exit interview, the HR person just said, "yeah, that's Amherst." NOT a good sign.

job_title: Peer Tutor and Grader for Microeconomics in Amherst, MA
pros: I'm a grader and a tutor for economics department here. Very flexible hours, a lot of guidance, and very decent salary. I have also worked as Facilities during the summer, and also in the alumni programs. It's a very good opportunity for me to talk to the Alums and hear their stories.
cons: Might be tough to balance academic load and doing these jobs, and also balancing all other aspects as a student. But having said that, the flexibility given helps a lot. Sometimes it may be daunting to talk to an Alum, but all you need is some practice and courage! Academic departments are sometimes not too supportive of our efforts to seek out jobs in the real world.

review_title: Generally, Amherst College is a great place to work. Students come first.
pros: Amherst College is a great place for students to balance a study-work life that includes up to 15 hours a week of campus work in different facilities (library, physical plant, gym, safe ride, etc.). Also, because of college policy students come first, so student employees in financial need were able to keep their jobs during the recession even as some of the college's Staff positions were being compromised. Most supervisors will also bend over backwards to accommodate student's exam schedules - a lot of reshuffling takes place towards the end of every semester.
cons: The specific job's merits depend on the facility supervisor, which is why for example my experience at the Library was less than pleasant. Senior management was somewhat aggressive when I would call in a sick day. However, this is rather the exception than the rule.

review_title: It is the greatest undergraduate experience anyone could ask for.
pros:
The professors are very accessible. They have plenty of office hours in the week, and can be reached via email or separate appointments. 
The students are of the best quality in the world. Not a single one ever fell below my expectations. 
The facilities are also top-notch.
cons:
It may feel small at times. If you hook up with someone, it can feel weird seeing them around campus all the time. Also, the town of Amherst is nice, but it is far from a bustling, lively college town. Everything closes before 1 or 2 AM, even on weekends. 
Also, beware of overzealous feminists who will shame you for you "heteronormativity."

review_title: Easy job, great people to work with
job_title: Campus Center Manager in Amherst, MA
pros: The supervisors (in the Office of Student Affairs) are amazing. They take out the time to check in personally with each employee, and genuinely care about how you are doing. The work is also pretty easy; you just have to be attentive at the front desk, go on rounds of the building regularly (e.g. to set up for events, make sure it's clean, etc), and handle daily problems as they arise, e.g. issues with the technical equipment.
cons: Literally none that I can think of.

pros: Great pay, plenty of hours, face paced, always changing, new challenges are always coming up, supportive staff and administration, extremely rewarding.
cons: It can be tough dealing with students and parents who insist they need to be admitted, which sometimes pushes the buttons of the admission staff.

job_title: Computer Science Tutor in Amherst, MA
pros:
-You get to set your own hours so it's very manageable to keep on top of other work


-Talking to the Comptrollers office about pay issues is really easy here. Never had a problem.
cons:
-You'll hear very little from the CS Department outside of who you're assigned to.


-While the pay per hour is okay, you'll really need to consider other jobs on top of this if you really want more salary.

review_title: The institution challenged me with work projects and provided a constructive work culture.
pros: The culture of Amherst College is progressive and supportive of all employees. Interacting with students at the college was always enjoyable and entertaining.
cons: Roles of employees at Amherst College are often ill-defined and ambiguous. I found myself completing work that my supervisors could have completed themselves.

pros: Flexible hours, and great Primary investigators who care immensely about the research and about your development throughout the research experience. The staff associated with the research, at least in the Biology and Neuroscience departments, are super helpful and always willing to lend a hand.
cons: it is easy to get stuck in lab for long hours, or put in too much work for yourself.

review_title: Working as a student for any dept at Amherst is great
